I never get tired of this! I've always been excited about the possibilities of crewed spaceflight, but Elon and Bezos and others are working to make it a reality. Super psyched about the Moon in the next few years and, of course, cannot wait for the day the first crewed mission to Mars lifts off. Humanity’s return to the Moon will be amazing – but I suspect the first footsteps on Mars will be one of those “where were you when…” moments that transcend the artificial barriers we’ve constructed among members of our species.  Go SpaceX, (and Blue Origin, and Rocket Lab and NASA), and GO TIM for sharing your enthusiasm with all of us. Keep up the great work!
8 1/2 hours to see the first SpaceX crew launch... at the last second Tim blocks the view of the rocket with his butt.  GREAAT!@

0:00 pad stream starts
4:30:54 crew suiting up
4:37:39 Tim’s commentary begins
5:09:50 crew heads to pad

5:38:30 crew crosses access arm
5:43:24 crew boards dragon
6:16:20 hatch closed

8:29:39 LIFTOFF!

Proposed stream setup improvements for future events:
1. Make the font for the clock and current timeline item readable at minimum bandwidth (144p, Internet is getting congested).
2. Sync up all elements (camera angles, overlays, audio) to correspond to the same moment of real time, don't ignore the speed-of-sound delay for microphone locations like that 3 mile spot.
3. Have the mixer operator ready to bleep out incidental copyrighted snippets while keeping their delay within 10% of overall reality-to-stream delay.
4. Allow the handheld gear to efficiently piggyback on available WiFi without loosing sync. Try to keep at least one spare connection available at all times, using only a tiny bandwidth on the unused spare until it's needed.

I am watching this two days after this historic launch and I just love it.  This launch was as exciting to me as the Apollo  Launch was back in 1969 when we landed 2 men on the moon.  While so many took part in this historic launch, the one man that I keep thinking of and thanking is Elon Musk.  On Saturday, he saw his vision realized.  From videos that I have seen of his reactions, he was over the top and I just loved seeing his reaction.  Also, all of the young people taking part in this mission are doing more for our country and humanity and at the age of 61, I am thrilled to see that. They are doing more for our society than any of these angry rioters are doing now.  I look forward to many more SpaceX launches.  And thank you,  Elon Musk!

Tim, you do a great job with what you  do! Live interview with Jim and Elon on Tuesday, just 5km from Bob and Dough when they launch! A fool at work... I have followed the SpaxeX live stream all day on my Mac and yours on my TV. I will follow everything, until they get onto ISS... Let´s cross our fingers, that all the planned maneuvers go well and the automatic docking procedure works. Has anybody announced yet, how long they will stay? I understand, 117 days is max due to Dragons solar panels. So, close to 4 months. Could they overlap with Crew-1? I guess, not because Demo 2´s re-entry and landing needs to be evaluated before Crew1 can launch? I am some kind of confused here about this. Also, can an uncrewed Starliner dock ISS, while Dragon "Endeavour" is still there? Or Crew-1? I know, there are 2 international docking ports on ISS. Maybe you have talked about these things, while I had muted your audio and watched the SpaceX stream. Dont´t worry to comment here, I am sure, I will get the answers. Keep On!
